campus_walk_1.text: The soft hum of distant conversations fills the air as Sage walks through the bustling campus. The spring semester has begun, but the weight of unfinished feelings from the fall still lingers. She adjusts her mint-green cardigan against the chill of the breeze.

campus_walk_2.speaker: Sage
campus_walk_2.text: Okay... Second semester, an experienced Freshman - now that I survived the first. I can handle this... right? Writing classes, reading classes, a ridiculously hard math class - all part of the fun? I am supposed to embrace this - love it even, so why does everything feel scary and overwhelming?

campus_walk_3.text: Students pass by, laughing, chatting easily. Sage's footsteps slow as a group of peers from her first semester cross her path—already deep in conversation.

campus_walk_4.speaker: Sage
campus_walk_4.text: They make it seem so easy. I would say hello, but…they do not seem at all worried about anything - I would be a downer to them… I should... keep moving.

campus_walk_5.text: A phone notification buzzes in her pocket, but she ignores it for now, focusing on the path ahead. She sighs quietly, her eyes scanning the campus, lingering on students who already seem at ease.

campus_walk_6.speaker: Sage
campus_walk_6.text: “I should feel better about this. But I don't.”

blake_encounter_1.text: As she approaches the dorms, Sage crosses paths with Blake who shares the same major as Sage —a sharp-eyed, confident student who is always at the top of the class. Blake spots her and approaches her wanting to talk about the great first semester.

blake_encounter_2.speaker: Blake
blake_encounter_2.text: “Hi Sage - Ready for another semester? I am so excited! I thought last semester was soooo much fun with all the new stuff we learned and the meaningful projects we were assigned, but this semester we get to do even more!”

blake_encounter_3.speaker: Sage
blake_encounter_3.text: Wow, she is exactly where I wish I were. Enjoying college, living the life, making the most of it all…that’s what I’m supposed to be - but I know I’m not - I don’t even belong in the same program as her - this could be soooo embarrassing - I would just die if she knew how inept I really am.

choices.text: Fake it till you Make it

blake_fakeit_1.speaker: Sage
blake_fakeit_1.text: “Oh of course - it will be great! And last semester was great too - if I choose to only think about the good times.”

blake_fakeit_2.speaker: Sage
blake_fakeit_2.text: Great - keep the positive thoughts in the front Sage….she does not need to see your insecurities.

blake_fakeit_3.speaker: Blake
blake_fakeit_3.text: “Okay, well, I guess I will see you later.”

blake_fakeit_4.text: Blake walks away, leaving Sage to her thoughts.

blake_honest_1.text: Sage stops and faces Blake, meeting her gaze with a newfound resolve.

blake_honest_2.speaker: Sage
blake_honest_2.text: “Well, I’m still here, but honestly, last semester was tough for me. I was just relieved to pull through.”

blake_honest_3.text: Blake raises an eyebrow, but offers encouragement

blake_honest_4.speaker: Blake
blake_honest_4.text: “You know, most of us were… struggling last semester. I think I finally figured out how to study. Chin up - we’ve all been there!”

blake_honest_6.text: Her words linger long after she’s gone.

blake_honest_7.text: Sage turns and walks away, her steps echoing as she goes.

dorm_arrival_1.text: Sage walks into her dorm lobby, the scent of old coffee lingers from the communal kitchen, a stale reminder of late-night study sessions.

dorm_arrival_2.text: She looks around – everyone seems busy with the first round of exams and project deadlines soon approaching. She eyes the calendar on the wall–

dorm_arrival_3.speaker: Sage
dorm_arrival_3.text: Three weeks into the semester - how can I already be so far behind?

dorm_arrival_4.text: Looking around she sees a few dorm-mates watching One Piece.

dorm_arrival_5.speaker: Sage
dorm_arrival_5.text: oooohhhh, I could just sit and join them and take a break for a while - I really love that show.

dorm_arrival_6.text: She checks her phone— a missed call from home and a reminder from a professor about an upcoming assignment.

dorm_arrival_7.speaker: Sage
dorm_arrival_7.text: “Great. Deadline approaching – I am always behind and it has to be done well or there goes my grade, my GPA, my entire academic standing - lose my scholarship - get kicked out - never get a good job - “aaaaaaaccccckkkkkk!”

dorm_arrival_9.text:
She heads upstairs, swiping her keycard and pushing open the door to her dorm room.
It’s quiet—almost too quiet.

dorm_arrival_10.text: Sage sighs as she sits at her desk, the assignment staring back at her. The instructions seem to blur together as Sage forces her attention back into place.

dorm_striveA_1.speaker: Sage
dorm_striveA_1.text: I better get started, I know that I need the A or I will not be happy.

dorm_striveA_2.text: She decides to work on the project for several hours.

dorm_striveA_3.text: Sage stands up and stretches, she is finally satisfied that she will get an A on the assignment. She looks at the time - it's late - after midnight - did she even eat dinner?

dorm_reasonable_1.speaker: Sage
dorm_reasonable_1.text: Since this is due tomorrow, I better prioritize my time. I can start the assignment and set a timer to take a dinner break in one hour so I can come back and evaluate my progress with a clear mind.

dorm_reasonable_2.text: Sage works on the assignment for an hour and stops for dinner before returning to the assignment

dorm_reasonable_3.speaker: Sage
dorm_reasonable_3.text: Have I met the criteria - let me check - yep - but I could add to this and really wow my professor. That would ensure I got an A.

dorm_reasonable_4.text: She looks at the time - it's 7:30 and her roommates are talking about the weekend - she looks at her assignment and decides it is sufficient. She joins her friends and connects with them before getting ready for bed.

phone_call_1.text: The next morning, Sage wakes as her phone buzzes again—this time, a text from home. She hesitates before answering, staring at the screen as if it might bite.

phone_call_2.speaker: Sage
phone_call_2.text: What do they want now? A progress report? A lecture on how I’m not living up to my potential?

phone_call_3.text: The phone rings as Sage hesitates. Finally, she answers, her voice laced with a forced lightness.

phone_call_4.speaker: Parent
phone_call_4.text: “Hey, sweetheart. How’s the grind? Are you feeling okay about your schoolwork?”

phone_call_5.text: The concerned voice reminds Sage that even her family is worried.

phone_vague_1.speaker: Sage
phone_vague_1.text: “Oh, you know…same old thing, nothing too exciting. I am just busy as always.”

phone_vague_2.speaker: Parent
phone_vague_2.text: “Well, busy is good. Just stay focused. We know you can do this. You’ve always been so bright.”

phone_vague_4.speaker: Sage
phone_vague_4.text: Soooo bright, so capable, can do it all - can’t you see that does NOT help! I am drowning here and talking just feels like more expectations to live up to.

phone_vague_5.speaker: Sage
phone_vague_5.text: “Well, I’m sorry to cut you short, but I have to get to a study group. Talk to you later, love you.”

phone_honest_1.speaker: Sage
phone_honest_1.text: “It’s… kind of overwhelming, honestly. I feel like I’m already behind.”

phone_honest_2.speaker: Parent
phone_honest_2.text: “Well, that’s normal. You’re doing fine, Sage. You always put too much pressure on yourself. Don’t overthink it. Just keep your head down and work hard - you know, do the best you can.”

phone_honest_4.speaker: Sage
phone_honest_4.text: Can’t you see that “doing my best” all the time is exhausting, not to mention impossible to maintain. I am eventually going to fail and let you down. (feels tears welling)

phone_honest_5.speaker: Parent
phone_honest_5.text: “You’ll be fine. Just remember why you’re there. To get a good education, to build a future. We’re all rooting for you.”

phone_honest_6.speaker: Sage
phone_honest_6.text: “I know you are, and I know you believe in me, but I really feel like I am going to burn out. Sometimes I feel so scared to let you down - I really want to make you proud of me.”

phone_honest_7.speaker: Parent
phone_honest_7.text: “Oh Sage. No honey, really, there is nothing you can do to make me love you less and I am already so VERY proud of you. You only have to make yourself proud. Make choices that you believe in, not the ones you think we want from you. Sage - hear me on this - we love you unconditionally - you are enough.”

phone_honest_8.speaker: Sage
phone_honest_8.text: Why does everything feel so heavy? Like I’m carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders. It’s not that I don’t feel loved, I just - well - I hope I don't let anyone down.

phone_call_6.text: Regardless of the choice, the call ends with a feeling of subtle but familiar pressure. Sage stares at the phone after hanging up.

social_invite_1.text: It’s now Friday and campus is emptying quickly as students rush to get to their weekend plans. A notification pops up: a group from one of Sage’s classes is organizing a casual study meet-up at the campus coffee shop.

social_invite_2.text: The message reads: "Join us for some study and chill! No pressure!" She hovers over the message, torn between the allure of connection and the safety of isolation.

social_accept_1.speaker: Sage
social_accept_1.text: Sage types a quick reply: "I’m in. See you guys there!"

social_accept_2.speaker: Sage
social_accept_2.text: Maybe this’ll help. I could certainly use some group study since I am not doing great with the subject matter. And maybe if I’m around other people, I won’t feel so alone. I can’t do everything alone, right?

social_accept_3.text: Sage puts her phone away, packing her backpack and primping up a bit before heading out.

social_accept_4.text: Sage gets back late, the study session was helpful but now she is exhausted - and heads straight to bed.

social_ignore_1.text: She closes the message without replying, her thumb hovering over the "mute notifications" button.

social_ignore_2.speaker: Sage
social_ignore_2.text: No point in going, I’ll just make a fool of myself. I can figure it out myself, I always do. Besides, socializing is so taxing!

social_ignore_3.text: Her decision lingers as the silence feels heavier now. She works on homework for a while and then heads to bed.

dream_seq_transition.text: That night...Sage is tossing in her bed...surreal and emotional dreams plaguing her sleep.

dream_entrance.text: WELCOME to the Stress & Anxiety Carnival
